channel.title: Client Hacking Group
channel.description: I was thinking we could start a group for people interesting in client hacking and looking at the new runescape client. We would not need a website or anything, we could just talk together on msn. I am learning java now, so I would not be to much of a help :rolleyes: but I am sure I could do something. What do you guys think about this?

item.title: Client Hacking Group
item.dc:creator: @Kryptizzler Kryptizzler
item.description:
@Kryptizzler wrote:

Well then fucking read the fucking topic and don’t bring up fucking old threads.

Ok. Here’s your answer. No. You can’t just hack someones MSN account, because people wouldn’t use it if it was so insecure. So, they need to have a strong ‘anti-hack’ system.

Read full topic

item.title: Client Hacking Group
item.dc:creator: @jcp jcp
item.description:
@jcp wrote:

[quote=“Teh Freak, post:17, topic:2978”]The new client, in most ways, has not changed dramatically, i have been able to output item info, npc info, npo (Object) info, item images, the rs fonts for my font parser, and other varous things, if i can do all of that by myself in a limited amount of time, i’m quite sure others can too, to become familiar, just look at an old aryan renamed source, its very useful, you can easily compare methods, rename the a lot, so i wish you the best of luck, maybe you’ll find something worth doing.[/quote]m, and work your wayu around, me and pd went throughout the 403 client that was released, and renamed a fair amount of it, between the 2 of us, we got loads done, so if you find yourself some people willing to learn, you can accomplish

Working with a few people on the client sounds like a good idea. I will try to find a few people who want learn with me. Can I help you analyze the client sometime?

Read full topic

item.title: Client Hacking Group
item.dc:creator: @Teh_Freak Teh Freak
item.description:
@Teh_Freak wrote:

The new client, in most ways, has not changed dramatically, i have been able to output item info, npc info, npo (Object) info, item images, the rs fonts for my font parser, and other varous things, if i can do all of that by myself in a limited amount of time, i’m quite sure others can too, to become familiar, just look at an old aryan renamed source, its very useful, you can easily compare methods, rename them, and work your wayu around, me and pd went throughout the 403 client that was released, and renamed a fair amount of it, between the 2 of us, we got loads done, so if you find yourself some people willing to learn, you can accomplish a lot, so i wish you the best of luck, maybe you’ll find something worth doing.

Read full topic

item.title: Client Hacking Group
item.dc:creator: @wL1 wL
item.description:
@wL1 wrote:

[quote=“Asm, post:14, topic:2978”]2wL:
RESPECT!
I’m thinking about the same stuff
However it should be easier to write very own version of Java Runtime (especially ClassLoader)
It will allow us to dump original classes to disk to analyze it later for variables/methods we need in client
And later modify classes while loading ‘on the fly’
Current sources looks like server may request the value of any variable or even execution of arbitary method so ‘renaming’ is in the past…
Client code looks like practical applying of classical obfuscation algorithms like
FSM and ‘always-true / always-false’ predicates
I think rs cheating is going to third generation: in-memory bytecode patching
however i do not have time for this due to exams :P[/quote]
Hacking the runtime class libraries is rather simple but your possibilities are limited. And runtime analysis is not possible which could be very useful. You can however do other useful things like redirect connections or disabling the RSA encryption which I already did in the past.
PS: isn’t it a pity that having skill and having a lot of spare time are mutual exclusive

Read full topic

Mind telling me which VM you used? Suns SCSL Source?

I think it was Sable.

PS: Isn’t it weird that some interest in rs hacking awoke in me after the new client was released. I mean I stopped caring about RS for ages. Dam challenges.

I know what you mean

Read full topic

item.title: Client Hacking Group
item.dc:creator: @wL1 wL
item.description:
@wL1 wrote:

[quote=“Krichevskoy, post:7, topic:2978”][quote author=Ben link=topic=3362.msg32542#msg32542 date=1147897250]
lol working with the client as it is now is near impossible, it’ll be easier to really hack it with C++ and generate events and steal information directly from the memory – Which is probably above most of this forum’s users if not all of them.

Learning Java to edit the client is useless now.
[/quote]

You couldn’t be more wrong (well, maybe if you were suggesting that we all learn Ruby…:P)
I tried exactly what you’ve suggested once, and let me tell you that hacking the VM (which is what you suggest) is much, much more difficult than overcoming almost ANY Java obstacle that Jagex throws at us.[/quote]
Mind telling me which VM you used? Suns SCSL Source?
And this guy might be right that it is simpler to properly recode the VM such that it easily allows us code/data inspection and code injection. It would be easier than always bother with new restructured client versions. If done properly, universal signatures can be used to trace data we seek. I have made some thoughts on this and came up with a couple of ideas, yet no time to implement and try those. One approach might be to monitor the “temporal evolution” (this could be done in a rather controlled way to reduce any influences of randomness, though, if done right, shouldn’t be a critical point) of each variable (be it global or local), method invokation, interelations between those objects and the like and create some reasonable data out of it on basis of a statistical analysis. This data should be feasible identify fields and methods of our interest.
But the main advantage is, that there’s very little chance for jagex (unless they do a system scan which can be detected and prohibited easily ) to detect a VM that was being tampered with.
AFAIK, jegax randomly checks whether the client has been tampered with using reflection, and it requires quite some care to properly handle this. IHMO it is pointless to waste any more time on bots based on modified java clients. They can add new nuiscances as we speak here. One should not stick with outdated concepts, one should go with the time and eventually try something new. It is in our nature to advance (well, at least in mine and certainly some other people too).
That said, I have to note that in order to realize such a project you’d have to be a very skilled and experienced coder (otherwise you’re not even able to understand how the VM works), of course you should be familiar with java/bytecode and also ASM knowledge is of advantage for the JIT engine. Plus you need to have a lot spare time to burn and your ambition shouldn’t be any less.
I doubt anyone here falls into the class of fulfilling all the requirements.
So this probably remains a vision :o

PS: Isn’t it weird that some interest in rs hacking awoke in me after the new client was released. I mean I stopped caring about RS for ages. Dam challenges.

Read full topic
